faqs.q: How do River's fees compare to staying on an exchange?
faqs.a: River's trading fee starts at 1% and drops to 0.25% as your volume grows. Recurring buys skip fees entirely after the first week, and you can pair that with Auto-withdraw to move sats to self-custody automatically—though keeping some balance on River for active trading can make sense depending on your workflow.

faqs.q: When can I withdraw ACH-funded bitcoin to my own wallet?
faqs.a: ACH deposits trade instantly but stay pending about seven days until settlement clears. Once funds move to available balance you can withdraw to self-custody. River holds the keys during that time, which introduces the usual custodial and counterparty considerations.

faqs.q: What's the exit path for moving sats off River?
faqs.a: Lightning withdrawals are free and instant once your balance is available. On-chain offers Priority, Standard, and Flexible tiers depending on how quickly you need confirmation. Auto-withdraw can move sats automatically when you hit a threshold, though manual withdrawals give you more control over timing and fee selection.

faqs.q: What's the trade-off with Bitcoin Interest on Cash?
faqs.a: River pays 3.5% APY on idle cash and converts interest to bitcoin monthly. Your cash stays custodial during this time, which means trusting River's reserves without per-user on-chain proof. Some people use this for working capital while moving long-term holdings to self-custody; others prefer to avoid custodial yield entirely.

faqs.q: Where is River available and what are the limits?
faqs.a: River serves U.S. residents, though some states face additional verification steps until local licensing clears. The service is custodial, which means River holds the keys while you use the platform—you can withdraw to self-custody at any time once your deposits settle.

recovery_method: Email login with optional 2FA. Support can reset access after you reverify your ID.
description:
River helps U.S. based customers invest in Bitcoin simply and securely with a focus on long-term saving. Unlike many platforms, River holds all Bitcoin in full-reserve cold storage with multi-signature security and gives users transparency through real-time proof of reserves. This might sound inviting to people who don't want to hold Bitcoin in self-custody but it also means more centralization within Bitcoin.

It supports things like inheritance planning, business accounts, and joint accounts, making it attractive for people who want to treat Bitcoin like serious money. Users can buy Bitcoin instantly, set up automated savings, and send Bitcoin via on-chain or Lightning payments. On top of that, you can earn 3.8% Bitcoin interest on your cash. The app has a clean interface and is designed to be easy to use, earning high ratings on both iOS and Android.

River's mission is to provide a trusted, high-quality experience for people who want to build wealth in Bitcoin without distractions. It aims to give users full control and transparency. While some users note strict ID verification and limited availability outside the U.S., River is praised for its reliability, personal customer service, and focus on security.

name: RoboSats

faqs.q: How do RoboSats Lightning bonds and escrow work?
faqs.a: Each contract starts with the maker posting a Lightning hold-invoice bond—defaults to ~3% of the trade—and the taker matching it when they join, while the seller locks the sats in a hold invoice escrow. That lock keeps funds frozen until both parties confirm fiat, which means you can complete the trade and reclaim everything or cancel during the timer if the peer stalls.

faqs.q: What fees does RoboSats charge on trades?
faqs.a: RoboSats collects 0.2% per completed trade, split 0.1% to the maker and 0.1% to the taker when the hold invoice settles. That sits on top of whatever spread you negotiate, so you can tighten your offers to keep the total cost in sats low.

faqs.q: Does RoboSats require KYC or accounts?
faqs.a: Instead of accounts, RoboSats generates a one-time robot avatar from a secret token you control and stores only that token locally. That keeps your personal data off the coordinator, and you can rotate a fresh robot for every trade to keep orders unlinkable.

faqs.q: Which Lightning wallets work best with RoboSats?
faqs.a: You need a Lightning wallet that can issue invoices and hold payments for a few minutes; RoboSats docs highlight Zeus, Blixt, Phoenix, Breez, Mutiny, and BlueWallet (LDK) because they keep the bond open until fiat clears. That support prevents premature expiry, and you can keep a second wallet with inbound liquidity ready if your main one is routing a large trade.

faqs.q: How are disputes handled if a counterparty does not release sats?
faqs.a: If fiat fails, you hit Dispute in the chat, upload the payment proof, and the coordinator reviews both bond invoices plus your evidence. Their ruling routes the trade hold invoice either to you or the counterparty, so you can recover funds when you documented the fiat leg.

description:
RoboSats is a privacy‑first, Lightning‑native peer‑to‑peer exchange for buying and selling bitcoin with fiat. It is open‑source, requires no registration or KYC, and runs primarily over Tor (with I2P and an Android app available). Each trade uses a one‑time “robot” identity tied to a secret token you control, and all peer chat is end‑to‑end encrypted with PGP. The flow is simple: make or take an order, both sides lock small Lightning bonds, the seller locks a Lightning hold‑invoice escrow, fiat moves, then sats are released.

What separates RoboSats is how deeply privacy and safety are built into the mechanics rather than bolted on. One‑trade identities reduce linkability across orders, PGP‑sealed chat prevents metadata leakage, and Lightning hold invoices act as both escrow and fidelity bonds to discourage cancellations and fraud. Pricing is transparent and market‑relative, fees are low at 0.2% split between maker and taker, and optional on‑chain payouts are handled via swaps. Clear best‑practice guides help users pick lower‑risk fiat rails and avoid chargeback traps.

The ideal audience is anyone who wants fast, low‑fee, no‑KYC bitcoin for modest amounts and is comfortable using Tor and a compatible Lightning wallet. Trade sizes are tuned to what routes reliably on Lightning today, which suits frequent smaller buys and sells. The UI is straightforward once you learn the token/robot model, and the documentation walks through wallet compatibility, order timing, disputes, and payment‑method hygiene to keep trades quick and clean.

RoboSats’ vision is to keep P2P bitcoin simple, private, and resilient, with a path toward a federated network of coordinators sharing a unified order book to reduce single‑operator risk while preserving the familiar UX.

tl_dr.best_for: Buyers who want no-KYC Lightning trades for small to mid-sized amounts and are comfortable living inside Tor.
tl_dr.consider_if: You value privacy enough to run a hold-invoice-capable wallet and double-check payment rails before committing fiat.
tl_dr.not_ideal_when: You need large clips, fiat chargeback protection, or hands-on support from a regulated desk.

fees_faq.a: Bonds auto-refund when both sides confirm fiat or if you cancel before the hold invoice is charged. That timer is enforced by the coordinator, so you can exit early if a counterparty disappears.

fees_faq.q: Who pays Lightning routing fees on RoboSats?
fees_faq.a: Each side pays the routing cost on the Lightning invoices they settle, which is usually just a few sats. You can keep fees negligible by using well-connected wallets or running your own node.

Record the experience: bond timing, chat etiquette, and payout process.
Decide whether the peer deserves a trust note for future trades.
tiles.gotcha: Skipping test trades raises the chance you discover a wallet or rail issue during a larger order.

tiles.title: 4. Sweep profits to long-term storage
tiles.why: Moving sats off your hot Lightning wallet preserves sovereignty and limits coordinator exposure.
actions: Use your wallet’s built-in swap (or Boltz) to move sats on-chain if you want cold storage.
Label the transaction with the RoboSats order ID for bookkeeping.
Consolidate to a hardware wallet or multisig when balances grow.
Archive the robot token with the trade receipt for future tax records.
tiles.gotcha: Leaving large balances in a hot Lightning wallet invites device loss and liquidity drains.

micro_faqs.q: Can RoboSats pay me on-chain instead of Lightning?
micro_faqs.a: RoboSats itself is Lightning-only, but you can set up a Boltz or Deezy swap after payout to land coins on-chain.

micro_faqs.q: What if my Lightning invoice expires before the seller releases sats?
micro_faqs.a: Regenerate the invoice inside the room and ask the seller to repost; the coordinator keeps the bond active while you refresh it.

micro_faqs.q: How do I confirm the sats arrived safely?
micro_faqs.a: Check your wallet balance and verify the payment hash matches the contract details; you can also watch it settle on your node or Lightning explorer.

Your browser generates PGP keys for each contract so only you and the counterparty can read chat transcripts.
Using the clearnet gateway exposes metadata to Cloudflare, while Tor or I2P keeps IP data hidden.
privacy.data_flows_do: Stay on Tor or I2P and clear local storage after you finish each robot session.
privacy.data_flows_dont: Reuse the same robot token across multiple trades or share it in public rooms.
recovery: Click Recover robot and paste your token to reopen the order on another device.
If a timer expires with no dispute, bonds release automatically to the wallets that posted them.
Attach screenshots or bank receipts inside the encrypted chat so the coordinator can review them during disputes.

privacy.recovery_dont: Post the token or chat logs in public support channels.

micro_faqs.q: Does RoboSats log my IP address?
micro_faqs.a: When you use Tor or I2P the coordinator never sees your IP; only the optional clearnet gateway collects standard web logs.

micro_faqs.q: Can I delete my robot data after a trade?
micro_faqs.a: Yes. Clear your browser storage or hit Delete robot, and only your local token copy remains.

micro_faqs.q: What if the coordinator goes offline mid-trade?
micro_faqs.a: Trades pause until the coordinator returns; keep your wallet online and watch the RoboSats Matrix status channel for updates.

name: Sparrow

faqs.q: How does Sparrow connect to my Bitcoin node?
faqs.a: Sparrow talks to Bitcoin Core or an Electrum server to fetch your balance and broadcast transactions. If you use a public server, you share your privacy with that operator. Connecting to your own node means you validate the chain yourself and leak no data to third parties. You can configure this in the Server settings tab immediately.

faqs.q: Does Sparrow support hardware wallets?
faqs.a: Yes. Sparrow acts as the interface (watch-only wallet) for your hardware device. That means your private keys never touch the internet-connected computer, preventing malware from stealing your funds. You can connect almost any hardware wallet via USB or air-gapped via QR code/SD card to sign transactions securely.

faqs.q: Can I mix my coins with Sparrow?
faqs.a: Sparrow integrates Whirlpool to break the link between your past and future transactions. Most wallets leave a transparent trail on the blockchain that surveillance firms track. Mixing mathematically severs those links by combining your inputs with others. You can mix your funds directly within the app to regain your financial privacy.

faqs.q: Is Sparrow a hot wallet or a cold wallet?
faqs.a: It can be either, depending on how you set it up. If you create a software wallet with keys on your computer, it is a hot wallet suitable for small amounts. If you connect a hardware device like a Coldcard, Sparrow becomes a cold storage interface. That flexibility lets you use the same software for daily spending and deep cold storage.

faqs.q: Why is coin control important in Sparrow?
faqs.a: Coin control reveals the individual chunks of bitcoin (UTXOs) that make up your balance. Without it, wallets automatically merge coins, potentially linking private non-KYC funds with public KYC funds. Sparrow lets you label and select specific coins for every spend. That means you maintain the privacy boundaries you have built.

recovery_method: Manual seed backup
node_connect: Yes – Bitcoin Core or Electrum server (Tor supported)
description:
Sparrow Wallet is a desktop Bitcoin wallet designed to give users full control over their bitcoin. It was created by developer Craig Raw and is open-source, privacy-focused, and ideal for both beginners and advanced users. The wallet works on Windows, macOS, and Linux.

What separates Sparrow from other wallets is its balance between simplicity and advanced features. Beginners can start with a basic hot wallet setup and gradually explore more complex features like hardware wallet integration, multisig vaults, and UTXO control—all within the same interface. It gives users direct visibility into how Bitcoin works, showing transaction details, input and output flows, and allowing for precise control over fees and coin selection. This level of transparency helps users understand and manage their funds more deliberately.

User reviews highlight how Sparrow scales with you as you learn. It is refered to as the most powerful and versatile Bitcoin wallet, and users praise its clean layout, customizable setup, and educational value. Despite its many features, the app's interface is considered clear and organized once users get past the initial learning curve.

Sparrow's vision is to offer users complete sovereignty over their bitcoin. It avoids mobile compromises and instead focuses on a desktop experience that can integrate with cold storage, your own node, and advanced privacy tools. For beginners who want to grow into more advanced use cases without switching wallets, Sparrow offers a flexible and educational path to full control.

tl_dr.best_for: Desktop users who want full control over their UTXOs, privacy, and hardware wallet connections.
tl_dr.consider_if: You want to mix your coins with Whirlpool or connect easily to your own node.
tl_dr.not_ideal_when: You need a mobile wallet or prefer a simplified interface without technical details.

steps.title: 1. Install and verify
actions: Download Sparrow for your OS (Windows, Mac, Linux) and verify the PGP signature.
Install the application and open the Welcome wizard.
Choose your server connection: Public server (easiest) or Private Electrum/Core (private).
steps.gotcha: Public servers see your transaction history. Connect to your own node for full privacy.

steps.title: 2. Create your wallet
actions: Select 'New Wallet' and choose a meaningful name.
Pick your policy (Single Signature or Multi Signature) and script type (Native Segwit recommended).
Select 'New or Imported Software Wallet' for a hot wallet, or 'Connected Hardware Wallet' for cold storage.
steps.gotcha: Write down your seed words on paper. Never save them digitally or take a photo.

steps.title: 3. Receive and control
actions: Click 'Get Next Address' in the Receive tab to generate a clean address.
Send a small test amount to verify everything works.
Use the UTXOs tab to see and label your new coins once they arrive.
steps.gotcha: Always verify the address on your hardware device screen if using one.

micro_faqs.q: Do I need a hardware wallet to use Sparrow?
micro_faqs.a: No. You can create a 'hot' software wallet secured by a password on your computer. However, for large amounts, pairing Sparrow with a hardware wallet keeps keys offline and much safer.

micro_faqs.q: What happens if my computer crashes?
micro_faqs.a: Your funds are on the blockchain, not in the software. As long as you have your 12 or 24-word seed phrase written down, you can restore your wallet on any other computer.

micro_faqs.q: Can I connect to my Umbrel/Start9 node?
micro_faqs.a: Yes. Sparrow connects easily to private nodes via local network or Tor. This gives you the strongest privacy model possible.

key_features.heading: Who holds your keys & what privacy you get

features.title: Coin control
bullets: Visualize UTXOs: See every individual coin chunk, freeze the ones you don't want to spend, and prioritize others.
Mandatory labeling: Sparrow encourages labeling every address so you know exactly where funds came from.
Privacy barriers: Prevent accidentally merging KYC coins with non-KYC coins by selecting inputs manually.
features.footer: Good for: Advanced privacy management. Trade-off: Requires manual effort for every transaction.

features.title: Built-in mixing
bullets: Whirlpool integration: Mix your coins with others in a decentralized way to break blockchain links.
Post-mix tools: Automatically separates mixed coins into a dedicated account for safe spending.
No extra software: Run the mixing cycle directly within the Sparrow interface.
features.footer: Good for: Regaining fungibility. Trade-off: Mixing fees and mining fees apply.

features.title: Airgapped signing
bullets: No direct connection: Pass transactions via QR code or SD card so your hardware wallet never touches the computer.
Watch-only mode: Sparrow builds the transaction; your offline device signs it.
Broad support: Works natively with Coldcard, Jade, Passport, and Keystone via QR standards.
features.footer: Good for: Maximum security against malware. Trade-off: Slower workflow than USB connection.

features.title: Flexible security policies
bullets: Single Signature: Standard wallet type; one seed controls everything.
Multi Signature: Combine keys (e.g., Coldcard + Ledger + Paper) to require M-of-N signatures.
Gap limits: Customizable gap limits for scanning large or complex wallet histories.
features.footer: Good for: Scaling from beginner to expert vaults without switching software.

recovery_heading: If this happens, can I still move my Bitcoin?

recovery_explainers.why: Sparrow is just an interface. Your bitcoin lives on the blockchain, secured by your private keys. That means the software or computer can be destroyed without losing funds, as long as you have your backup.
how: Install Sparrow on a new computer.
Select 'Import Wallet' and choose your keystore type (Mnemonic or Hardware).
Enter your 12/24 words or connect your hardware device to regain access.
recovery_explainers.gotcha: You must use the same derivation path and script type (e.g., Native Segwit) to see your history.

recovery_explainers.why: If you lose your seed phrase but still have the working wallet file and password, you can move funds immediately. If you lose both the seed and the wallet access, the bitcoin is gone forever.
how: Open Sparrow and use your password to unlock the wallet.
Immediately create a new wallet with a new seed phrase.
Transfer all funds from the compromised wallet to the new one.
recovery_explainers.gotcha: There is no 'forgot password' or customer support reset. You are the bank.

inheritance.intro: Sparrow is a self-custody tool with no built-in inheritance service; choose a path below.

cards.title: 1. DIY single-sig
cards.why: When you control a single seed plus passphrase, heirs need both pieces and clear instructions to restore the wallet. This works when you trust one person to find everything and execute carefully.
cards.risk_note: Single point of failure: if one piece is lost or the executor makes a mistake, funds can be locked or swept incorrectly. Use for small amounts only.
cards.action: Do this: Write a one-page instruction sheet today and store it where your executor can find it when needed.

cards.title: 2. DIY multisig
cards.why: A 2-of-3 or 3-of-5 multisig setup splits control across multiple keys held by you, family members, or trusted contacts. One lost key does not lock the funds, and no single person can move coins alone.
requirements: Distribute keys to different people or locations
Document the quorum policy (which keys must co-sign)
Provide restore instructions for each key holder
cards.risk_note: Setup complexity: requires understanding multisig wallets, secure key distribution, and coordination among multiple parties.
cards.action: Do this: Research multisig wallets, test a small setup, then migrate your main holdings when confident.

cards.title: 3. Provider-assisted
cards.why: Services like Unchained or AnchorWatch offer assisted multisig where they hold one key and provide inheritance tooling. Your heirs follow a documented claim process, and the provider co-signs after verifying identity.
requirements: Migrate Sparrow funds to assisted multisig provider
cards.risk_note: Provider dependency: introduces counterparty risk and KYC, but removes the burden of full technical management from heirs.
cards.action: Do this: Compare assisted multisig providers if your heirs are not technical.

tiles.benefit: No KYC Tor support
tiles.why: Sparrow is client-side software. It collects no data on its own, but your connection method determines who sees your activity.
tiles.summary: If you connect to a public server, the operator sees your IP and addresses. If you connect to your own node, no one sees anything. Sparrow stores all labels and wallet data locally on your machine.
bullets: Public Server: Shares IP and transaction interest with server operator.
Private Node: Zero leaks; you validate your own transactions.
Tor Proxy: Built-in toggle to route traffic through Tor for anonymity.
Local Data: Wallet files are encrypted on your disk; no cloud sync.
tiles.explainer_text: No. The software is open source and has no analytics or tracking code. However, the server you connect to can see your requests. Use a private node or Tor to prevent this.

tiles.title: Jurisdiction
tiles.why: Sparrow is software you run, not a service you log into. There is no company holding your data or funds, so there is no jurisdiction to compel.
tiles.summary: Because Sparrow is a standalone desktop application, it falls under the jurisdiction of wherever you physically are. There is no central server to subpoena and no user database to breach.
bullets: No Account: You don't sign up or provide email.
No Custody: You hold the keys; Sparrow is just the tool.
No Servers: Developers cannot disable your wallet or freeze funds.
tiles.explainer_text: No. Sparrow has no control over your keys or the Bitcoin network. Even if the website disappeared, your installed software would keep working, and your seed phrase would work in other wallets.

micro_faqs.q: Is Sparrow anonymous?
micro_faqs.a: The software identifies you in no way. However, on-chain transactions are public. Use Whirlpool and Tor within Sparrow to maximize anonymity.

micro_faqs.q: Does Sparrow report to tax authorities?
micro_faqs.a: No. Sparrow does not know who you are and has no data to report. You are responsible for your own compliance.

name: Start9
type_of_platform: Home server as software and / or hardware

faqs.q: How do I reach the StartOS dashboard on day one?
faqs.a: Connect your Server One, Server Pure, or DIY box to power plus Ethernet, keep your laptop or phone on the same LAN, and visit `http://start.local` to run the Start Fresh wizard. The UI walks you through choosing Start Fresh or Recovery so the device can provision itself.

faqs.q: How do Start9 backups work?
faqs.a: Open System → Create Backup, pick a physical drive or SMB network folder, enter your master password, and StartOS writes an encrypted archive while warning you to favor high-endurance storage. You can continue using the server while the job runs and confirm the timestamp under System → Backups.

faqs.q: How do I trust the StartOS Root CA for HTTPS?
faqs.a: Download the Root CA during onboarding, from the startos-info file, or later via System → Root CA, then follow the Linux/Mac/Windows/Android/iOS instructions to import it. Once installed, browsers open your `.local` URLs over HTTPS without warnings.

faqs.q: What hardware does StartOS support?
faqs.a: StartOS boots on Raspberry Pi and most x86_64 hardware, but the DIY guide warns Pis struggle with Bitcoin workloads, so plan for at least 8 GB of RAM and a 1 TB SSD on x86 if you need a full node. Lightweight services like password vaults or file shares can still live on Pi kits using high-endurance microSD cards.

faqs.q: How do I recover after a disk failure?
faqs.a: Flash StartOS, choose Recover, then pick Use Existing Drive, Transfer, or Restore from Backup to load your encrypted data onto the new disk. Transfer mode copies everything from the old drive to a larger replacement so your Tor and LAN addresses remain unchanged.

support: Community forums and Premium support (Free with device)
description:
Start9 (Start9 Labs) is the creator of the Embassy—a turnkey, self-hosted personal server and Bitcoin stack powered by their open-source StartOS. Their mission is to eliminate reliance on centralized third parties, placing privacy, decentralization, and individual autonomy at the forefront. Unlike other DIY solutions, Start9 aims to "level the playing field," offering plug-and-play hardware kits (like Server One and Server Pure) or a do-it-yourself image for Raspberry Pi or x86, all fully supported by their first-class community and expert support team.

Start9's target users are privacy-conscious individuals, Bitcoiners, and anyone seeking digital autonomy without sacrificing usability. They prioritize delivering polished self-sovereign computing with high-quality hardware, intuitive interfaces, and expert support (via Matrix) to onboard less technical users while remaining fully transparent and open-source. Users appreciate its robust foundation, modular update system (allowing single-service patching), backup ease, and strong headless health checking—compared to alternatives like Umbrel.

Looking forward, Start9 envisions a world where personal servers become the backbone of a sovereign internet and smart homes, enabling blockchain-native apps, decentralized messaging, password managers, file storage, and more. Their open hardware and software philosophy ensures that even if the company disappears, the ecosystem lives on—fully community-driven and censorship-resistant.
supported_network: Bitcoin Core, Lightning (LND and Core Lightning), and the StartOS marketplace catalog for Nextcloud, Vaultwarden, Matrix, Jellyfin, and other LAN-native services.
custody_control: Self-hosted (you run StartOS and hold all keys on hardware you own).
recovery_method: Encrypted backups to physical drives or SMB folders plus Recover/Transfer wizards to reuse or restore disks.

tl_dr.best_for: People who want StartOS to orchestrate Bitcoin, Lightning, and self-hosted apps while everything runs on their own metal.
tl_dr.consider_if: You want a curated, signed marketplace and Tor-ready remote access on a dedicated private server (plug-and-play or DIY).
tl_dr.not_ideal_when: You expect Raspberry Pi hardware to power a Bitcoin stack despite Start9’s warning, or you require fully permissive open-source licensing.

steps.title: 1. Flash the StartOS image
actions: **Skip this step** if you bought a Server One or Server Pure (it comes pre-flashed).
Download the latest `startos-...img.gz` release from GitHub and optionally verify the SHA256 hash.
Write the image to a microSD card or USB SSD with balenaEtcher, just as the flashing guide outlines.
steps.gotcha: Start9 reminds you that reflashing an SD card will erase every byte on it, so pull data you need before writing the image.

steps.title: 2. Boot and visit start.local
steps.sync_time: Initial block download can take many hours on SSD-based x86 hardware and is unreliable on Raspberry Pi kits.
actions: Connect the server to power plus Ethernet, keep your laptop/phone on the same LAN, and open `http://start.local`.
Choose Start Fresh or the Recovery path, then follow the on-screen prompts to provision the OS.
If you are migrating, pick Use Existing Drive or Transfer to reuse your previous data set.
steps.gotcha: The DIY guide explicitly warns that Raspberry Pi builds stall on Bitcoin workloads, so treat Pi as a light-duty appliance.

steps.title: 3. Trust the Root CA
actions: Download the server’s Root CA during onboarding, from the startos-info file, or later via System → Root CA.
Import the certificate using the Linux, Mac, Windows, Android, or iOS guides so browsers accept your `.local` sites.
Keep a copy handy so you can share it with every device that needs HTTPS access to StartOS.
steps.gotcha: Tor Browser ignores `.local` addresses, so trust the certificate in a standard browser on the LAN first.

steps.title: 4. Install services from the Marketplace
actions: Open Marketplace → Change to view Start9 and Community registries or add your own signed registry.
Install Bitcoin Core, Lightning, Electrs, Nextcloud, Vaultwarden, or other apps, then pin their widgets on the dashboard.
Use Service Dashboard, Actions, and Logs to monitor each container and keep an eye on shared storage under System.
steps.gotcha: Apps share CPU, RAM, and disk, so watch System → Storage before enabling heavy indexes or photo libraries.

micro_faqs.q: Can I reuse an existing StartOS data drive?
micro_faqs.a: Yes. During onboarding choose Recover → Use Existing Drive so the wizard mounts your old data disk and recreates the server with new credentials.

micro_faqs.q: How do I grab the Root CA again later?
micro_faqs.a: Go to System → Root CA, download the certificate, and send it to any device that needs trusted HTTPS access.

hardware_bom.heading: Hardware options
hardware_bom.intro: Start9 offers plug-and-play servers with lifetime support, or you can build your own using commodity hardware. Official servers guarantee compatibility; DIY builds save money but require you to manage the hardware.

builds.name: Server One
builds.use_case: Running a full Bitcoin stack + AI/Media apps
builds.tradeoff: You pay a premium upfront → You get a tested, plug-and-play device with lifetime support.
builds.assumptions: Includes power & cables. Just add Ethernet.
builds.gotcha: Higher entry cost than a DIY mini-PC.

builds.name: Server Pure
builds.tradeoff: You pay for open hardware → You remove Intel ME and closed-source firmware risks.
builds.assumptions: For users who need hardware-level trust.
builds.gotcha: Overkill unless you specifically need open firmware.

builds.name: DIY x86 Build
builds.tagline: Build it yourself to save cost.
builds.tradeoff: You save money → You handle assembly, flashing, and hardware troubleshooting.
builds.gotcha: Start9 support covers the OS, not your hardware quirks.

micro_faqs.q: Can I still use a Raspberry Pi?
micro_faqs.a: Yes, but Start9 warns that Pis struggle with Bitcoin workloads. Use them for lighter apps or lab testing only.

micro_faqs.q: What is the advantage of Server Pure?
micro_faqs.a: Server Pure runs Coreboot and has Intel Management Engine disabled, minimizing the risk of hardware-level backdoors.

fees_scenarios.title: Initial sync time
fees_scenarios.cost_context: Fast on Server One/Pure or NVMe builds; very slow on Raspberry Pi.
fees_scenarios.service_factor: StartOS runs a full Bitcoin Core node. It must verify the entire chain before you can use Lightning.
fees_scenarios.what_happens: The node downloads and validates ~600GB of history. This is CPU and disk intensive.
fees_scenarios.how_to_minimize: Use an NVMe SSD and wired Ethernet. If migrating, use the 'Recover' option to reuse existing data.
fees_scenarios.learn_more: Server One and Pure come with NVMe drives that handle this workload easily.

fees_scenarios.title: Disk growth
fees_scenarios.service_factor: Unified storage means media apps (Photos/Files) compete directly with chain data.
fees_scenarios.what_happens: Full-history nodes store the entire blockchain plus Lightning databases, logs, and app containers on your local drive.
fees_scenarios.how_to_minimize: Allocate at least a 1 TB SSD for full archival, or enable pruning to fit on smaller drives.
fees_scenarios.learn_more: You can upgrade storage later using the 'Transfer Data' wizard.

fees_scenarios.title: Power consumption
fees_scenarios.cost_context: Server One / Pure (similar to a laptop)
fees_scenarios.service_factor: StartOS runs 24/7 to route payments and serve apps, but uses efficient mobile processors.
fees_scenarios.what_happens: The device draws continuous power. Server One/Pure are far more efficient than a desktop tower.
fees_scenarios.how_to_minimize: Stick to official hardware or N100 mini-PCs. Old desktops can draw 100W+ idle.
fees_scenarios.learn_more: StartOS manages CPU scaling automatically to save power when idle.

fees_scenarios.title: Bandwidth requirements
fees_scenarios.service_factor: Bitcoin Core gossip and StartOS system updates consume significant data.
fees_scenarios.what_happens: The node stays in sync with the network. Backups to remote locations also use upload bandwidth.
fees_scenarios.how_to_minimize: Use wired Ethernet. If your ISP has caps, schedule backups for off-peak hours.
fees_scenarios.learn_more: Initial sync is the heaviest load; daily usage is light for most home connections.

fees_faq.q: Can I back up to a thumb drive?
fees_faq.a: StartOS strongly discourages low-quality flash media; the backup guide says to use high-endurance SSDs or SMB folders so archives stay intact.

fees_faq.q: What if my new disk is larger than the old one?
fees_faq.a: Follow the Transfer Data guide, which copies your data from the old drive to the new SSD before recreating the server.

key_terms.definition: A certificate you download from StartOS and import on every device so `.local` services open over HTTPS without warnings.

data_flows: LAN access uses `.local` URLs secured by your trusted Root CA, so only devices on the same network can reach the dashboard over HTTPS.

Native apps either embed Tor or rely on system-wide Tor proxies, so follow the platform guides before exposing credentials.
privacy.data_flows_do: Trust the Root CA on every device, keep the server behind your router, and use Tor Browser or Tor-enabled apps for remote sessions.
privacy.data_flows_dont: Skip the certificate import, open `.local` URLs from Tor Browser, or expose StartOS to the clearnet without a proxy.
privacy.recovery_title: Hardware failure? How StartOS recovery works
recovery: If the OS drive fails, flash StartOS, choose Recover, and point it at your existing data drive or encrypted backup archive.
Use Transfer mode to copy data from an old disk to a larger new one without changing your Tor or LAN addresses.
Store multiple backup targets—physical and network—so you always have a clean copy to restore.
privacy.recovery_do: Test a restore path before you need it and keep powered USB enclosures handy for migrations.
privacy.recovery_dont: Trust a single low-quality flash drive; Start9 explicitly warns backups need SSD-class media.
region: StartOS runs entirely on your hardware, so jurisdictional exposure is limited to where you host the server.
Tor connectivity means you do not need ISP port forwards or public IPs to reach the services remotely.

micro_faqs.q: Does StartOS support VPN remote access?
micro_faqs.a: Not yet—the remote access guide says VPN support is coming in a future release, so for now stick to Tor `.onion` URLs.

micro_faqs.q: Why do I need Bonjour on Windows?
micro_faqs.a: Windows lacks `.local` discovery by default, so the LAN guide instructs you to install Bonjour Print Services before opening StartOS over HTTPS.

try: Install Lightning, then run the built-in migration actions if you’re moving from Umbrel, RaspiBlitz, or myNode.
Follow the Zeus or AlbyHub guides to connect via REST, Tor, or Lightning Node Connect.
Use the LNbits action if you prefer to route payments through LNbits frontends.
compat_explainers.gotcha: After migrating, never restart the old node or it may broadcast stale channel states and cost you funds.

compat_explainers.why: Electrs, RPC bridges, and explorer apps live in the Marketplace so you can pair StartOS with Sparrow, Specter, or BTCPay.
try: Install Electrs and wait for the index to complete before pointing wallets at it.
Copy the LAN SSL endpoint for desktops and the Tor endpoint for mobile wallets.
Use the Bitcoin Integrations guide to wire Sparrow, Specter, or BTCPay to your node.
compat_explainers.gotcha: Electrs needs as much disk as Bitcoin plus its own index, so ensure the SSD has headroom before enabling it.

integrations.intro: Your node replaces the cloud when you wire wallets, remote control apps, and merchant tools straight to StartOS.

cards.title: Connect your wallet
cards.description: Use the Bitcoin Integrations guide to point Sparrow, Specter, or other Electrum-compatible wallets at your own Electrs index.
steps: Install **Electrs** from the Marketplace and wait for the index to complete.
Open the service details to copy the LAN SSL endpoint or the Tor address.
Paste the endpoint into your wallet’s server settings after trusting the Root CA.
cards.privacy: Your wallet now queries your own node, not third-party servers.

cards.title: Remote node control
cards.description: Lightning guides show how to pair Zeus, AlbyHub, or LNbits via REST, Tor, or Lightning Node Connect.
steps: Install the **Lightning** service but keep it offline until migration or channel setup is ready.
Run the migration action for your old node, entering its LAN IP and passwords.
Scan the LNDconnect string or LNC QR code from StartOS inside Zeus or AlbyHub.
cards.privacy: All traffic routes over Tor so no VPN or port forwarding is required.

cards.title: Merchant & tools
cards.description: Install BTCPay Server, LNbits, or other Marketplace apps so your storefronts talk directly to Bitcoin Core and Lightning.
steps: Browse the Marketplace for apps like **BTCPay**, **LNbits**, **Nextcloud**, or **Vaultwarden**.
Install the service, review the Service Dashboard to confirm dependencies, and copy its `.local` or `.onion` URL.
Pin the widget on the StartOS dashboard so you can monitor resource usage.
cards.privacy: Customer data never leaves your hardware unless you explicitly share it.

tasks.title: Create System Backup
tasks.intro: Backups are your safety net; Start9 warns against cheap thumb drives.
steps: Navigate to **System → Create Backup**.
Pick a physical SSD or pre-configured network folder and select the services you want to protect.
Enter the master password and let the archive complete before disconnecting the drive.

tasks.title: Test Restore Procedure
tasks.intro: A backup is only useful if you know how to restore it.
steps: Flash StartOS on spare hardware or a VM.
Choose **Recover → Restore from Backup** and point to your encrypted archive.
Verify the restored services start before wiping the test device.

tasks.title: Manage Registries
tasks.intro: Registries are critical infrastructure—track what you trust.
steps: Open **Marketplace → Change** and confirm which registries are enabled.
Remove registries you no longer need and document any custom URLs.
Check **System → Updates** before installing new builds, especially on production nodes.

tasks.title: Distribute Root CA
tasks.intro: Every device that hits StartOS over HTTPS needs the Root CA.
steps: Go to **System → Root CA** and download the certificate.
Transfer it securely (AirDrop, USB, encrypted chat) to other devices.
Follow the OS-specific instructions so browsers trust your `.local` sites.

security_model.overview: StartOS assumes a trusted LAN secured by your Root CA for local access and Tor `.onion` URLs for remote sessions.
quick_wins: Import the Root CA on every device so `.local` dashboards load over HTTPS.
Keep the server on wired Ethernet behind your router and avoid exposing clearnet ports.
Use Tor Browser or Tor-enabled apps when you are off-network.
hardening: Favor powered SSD enclosures or high-endurance microSD cards as Start9 recommends, especially on Pi-class hardware.
Maintain multiple backup targets (physical and SMB) so you have options if a drive dies.
Treat third-party registries cautiously; verify `.s9pk` signatures before installing.

migration.title: Reuse an existing data drive
migration.choose: Use this when you re-flash StartOS but want to keep the previous data disk.
steps: Flash StartOS, choose **Recover**, and select **Use Existing Drive**.
Pick the correct data disk from the list (refresh if necessary).
Set a new master password and let StartOS re-initialize with your old data.
migration.tips: Label your drives so you never confuse the old and new disks.
migration.gotcha: Selecting the wrong drive will erase it; double-check before confirming.

migration.title: Transfer data to a new drive
migration.choose: Use when you are upgrading to a larger SSD or moving to new hardware.
steps: Shut down the server, install the new internal drive, and connect the old drive via USB.
Flash StartOS, choose **Recover → Transfer**, and select the old drive as the source and the new drive as the destination.
Enter your master password and let the migration finish; StartOS keeps your Tor/LAN addresses intact.
migration.tips: Use the fastest USB enclosure you have to shorten the copy window.
migration.gotcha: The guide warns that multi-terabyte copies can take many hours—leave the system powered the whole time.

migration.title: Migrate LND to StartOS
migration.choose: Use when you are moving LND funds from Umbrel, RaspiBlitz, or myNode without closing channels.
steps: Install the Lightning service on StartOS but do not start it; the wallet must be untouched.
Run the migration action for your old node, entering its LAN IP and passwords.
Once StartOS reports success, power down the old node and then start Lightning on StartOS.
migration.tips: Keep both nodes on the same LAN so the migration script can reach the old REST API.
migration.gotcha: Never restart the old node after migrating—broadcasting stale states could cost you funds.

cards.fact: Docs cover StartOS 0.3.5.x with up-to-date user manual links.
Source-available StartOS builds ship via the official GitHub releases.
Root CA & Tor connection guides help you secure LAN and remote access.

trust.summary: StartOS keeps everything on hardware you own, documents each step in the 0.3.5.x manual, and publishes source-available builds plus Root CA guidance so you understand the trust model.

name: Strike

faqs.q: How do Strike's bitcoin trading fees work?
faqs.a: Strike charges a tiered Strike fee that starts at 0.99% for monthly volume under $250 and steps down to 0.39% once you trade more than $15,000,000. Recurring purchases skip the fee after the first cycle for hourly or daily schedules and after the second run for weekly or monthly schedules.

faqs.q: When are ACH deposits available to withdraw?
faqs.a: ACH deposits post instantly for trading but sit in your pending balance until the transfer settles, which typically takes about five business days plus any extra hold Strike applies based on your history. Once the deposit moves to available balance you can send, spend, or withdraw it.

faqs.q: Are Lightning withdrawals free?
faqs.a: Yes. Lightning withdrawals from your available bitcoin balance have no Strike fee and settle instantly once your ACH or card deposit has cleared.

faqs.q: How do bitcoin auto-withdrawals work?
faqs.a: You can set a threshold between 1,000,000 and 500,000,000 sats along with one or more payout addresses. When your available balance crosses the threshold Strike queues the full amount, gives you a 12 hour window to cancel, then broadcasts within 24 hours using the fee-free Flexible tier.

faqs.q: Where is Strike available today?
faqs.a: Strike is available across the United States except New York, Puerto Rico, and in more than 95 other countries. Availability and payment methods vary, so confirm support in your local App Store or on the Strike website.

WW.text: Live on bitcoin with Bill Pay
Recurring bitcoin buys with fee waivers
ACH deposits must clear before withdrawals

US.text: Bill Pay converts paychecks to bitcoin

recovery_method: Email login with optional 2FA and support assisted resets
description:
Strike is a custodial bitcoin app focused on fast buys and cash like payments. The mobile interface puts bank, card, and direct deposit funding beside instant Lightning withdrawals, so you can move from fiat to bitcoin and back with minimal steps.

Funding options cover fee-free ACH, debit cards with a small processor fee, and same day wires. ACH deposits trade instantly yet stay pending for roughly five business days before you can withdraw, while wires settle in about one business day and debit card purchases clear immediately.

Recurring purchases waive the Strike fee after the first cycle, and optional auto-withdrawals move your balance to self custody once it reaches the threshold you set. Customer prompts inside the app highlight fee tiers, settlement speed, and the 12 hour cancel window Strike gives you before broadcasting auto-withdrawals.

tl_dr.best_for: Buyers who want to DCA and withdraw over Lightning without extra fees.
tl_dr.consider_if: You need bank or debit funding with predictable limits and recurring buys.
tl_dr.not_ideal_when: You require support for other cryptocurrencies or desktop trading.

steps.title: 1. Create & verify
actions: Install Strike from App Store or Google Play and sign up with your email
Submit your government ID photo and provide your legal name, address, and SSN
Wait for verification to complete—contact support if it takes longer than 24 hours
steps.gotcha: Limits stay conservative until verification clears.

steps.title: 2. Fund (ACH / card / SEPA)
actions: Open Account → Payment methods and link your bank via Plaid or add a debit card
Review your deposit limits for ACH, card, or wire before funding
Deposit cash—ACH trades instantly but stays pending ~5 business days before withdrawal
steps.gotcha: ACH sits in pending ~5 biz days before you can withdraw.

steps.title: 3. Buy & withdraw
steps.why: Own bitcoin and move it to your wallet.
actions: Tap Buy Bitcoin, enter an amount, or set up a recurring purchase to dollar-cost average
Test withdrawal: tap Bitcoin → Send, scan a Lightning invoice or paste a Bitcoin address, and send a small amount (~$5–$10)
Once verified, send the rest—Lightning is instant and free; on-chain offers Priority (~10 min), Standard (~1 hour), or Flexible (~24 hours, free)
steps.gotcha: Flexible on-chain is free but ~24h; Standard ~1h.

micro_faqs.q: How long does Strike verification take?
micro_faqs.a: Strike verification typically completes within a few minutes, though it can take up to 24 hours during high volume. If your account isn't approved within 24 hours, contact Strike support with your sign-up email.

micro_faqs.q: Can I buy bitcoin on Strike without verification?
micro_faqs.a: No. Strike requires full identity verification before you can deposit funds or buy bitcoin. You must submit a government-issued ID and complete KYC to meet regulatory requirements.

micro_faqs.q: What's the fastest way to buy bitcoin on Strike?
micro_faqs.a: Link a debit card for instant deposits and immediate bitcoin purchases. Card funds are available to withdraw right away, while ACH deposits trade instantly but stay pending about five business days before you can send bitcoin off Strike.

fees_scenarios.learn_more: Deposit limits start at $1,000 per seven days for ACH and can scale to $100,000, while wire and direct deposit limits are unlimited.

fees_scenarios.learn_more: Auto-withdrawals queue for 12 hours before broadcast and settle within 24 hours, and ACH funded bitcoin must reach available balance before leaving Strike.

fees_faq.q: Does Strike charge network fees on Lightning withdrawals?
fees_faq.a: Strike covers the Lightning routing cost, so you only pay the invoice amount. On-chain withdrawals still depend on the mining fee tier you pick.

fees_faq.q: When does my Strike fee tier reset?
fees_faq.a: Strike resets monthly trading volume at 00:00 UTC on the first day of the new month, placing you back on the highest fee tier until you trade again.

fees_faq.q: Can I change the speed of an on-chain withdrawal after I send it?
fees_faq.a: You cannot edit a broadcast once Strike submits it, but you can pick Priority, Standard, or Flexible before confirming, and auto-withdrawals give you a 12 hour cancel window.

compat_explainers.why: Pay bills directly from your Strike balance while maintaining bitcoin exposure. Convert your paycheck to bitcoin via direct deposit, then let Strike handle rent, utilities, and credit cards automatically.

Bills auto-pay from your chosen balance each month

compat_explainers.why: Access cash without selling your bitcoin. You retain ownership and future upside while Strike holds your bitcoin as collateral. Be careful with leverage and use a small amount of your own money to cover the loan.

Choose your loan amount and add the required bitcoin collateral
Review the Loan Agreement (interest rate, liquidation threshold, repayment terms)
Receive cash in your Strike account after approval
compat_explainers.gotcha: If bitcoin's price drops below the liquidation threshold, Strike may sell your collateral to cover the loan. Loan availability and minimums vary by state. You give up self-custody while bitcoin sits as collateral.

compat_explainers.why: Set up recurring purchases to automatically buy bitcoin at regular intervals, building your position over time without timing the market.

Choose your schedule: hourly, daily, weekly, or monthly

After the first cycle completes, all future orders are free

tiles.title: 1. Pick a cold storage wallet

Buy and initialize your hardware wallet or install cold storage software
Generate a new seed phrase and write it down on paper
Store your seed phrase in a fireproof safe or safety deposit box

Generate a new receive address in your wallet software
Copy the Bitcoin address (starts with bc1, 1, or 3)

actions: In Strike: tap Bitcoin > Send > Bitcoin wallet
Paste your hardware wallet's fresh Bitcoin address
Send $5–$10 worth of bitcoin using Standard tier (~1 hour)

Send the rest of your balance and store your hardware wallet securely

micro_faqs.q: Why should I use cold storage?
micro_faqs.a: Cold storage keeps your bitcoin offline, protecting it from hackers and online threats. Hardware wallets provide military-grade security for long-term holding.

micro_faqs.q: How do I verify my withdrawal arrived?
micro_faqs.a: Check your hardware wallet's transaction history or use a block explorer like mempool.space. On-chain transactions confirm within 10 minutes to 24 hours depending on your fee tier.

micro_faqs.q: What's the safest way to store my seed phrase?
micro_faqs.a: Memorize your 12-24 word seed phrase or write it on paper or metal. Store copies in separate secure locations like a fireproof safe and safety deposit box. Never store it digitally.

name: Swan

faqs.q: How do Swan's bitcoin purchase fees work?
faqs.a: Swan waives fees on your first $10,000 in lifetime buys, then charges 1% on each additional buy or sell. Auto-withdrawals keep Swan Safe custody fees waived so you do not pay the optional 0.03% monthly charge.

faqs.q: When are ACH deposits available to withdraw from Swan?
faqs.a: ACH purchases under $1,000 typically unlock in 10–15 days (closer to 5–10 days once your account is seasoned), while larger ACH purchases unlock in 20–30 days; wires and bitcoin deposits settle within about 24 hours. Use the “Available to withdraw” banner in your dashboard to see exact dates.

faqs.q: Does Swan charge for bitcoin withdrawals?
faqs.a: Swan does not add a platform fee when you withdraw bitcoin; you simply pick the on-chain fee tier that matches the speed you want. USD wires carry a $15 fee with a $50,000 minimum if you move cash instead of bitcoin.

faqs.q: How do Swan auto-withdrawals work?
faqs.a: Add a wallet address under Withdrawals, enable two-factor authentication, and set the on-chain balance threshold that fits your cadence. Once your unlocked balance crosses that mark, Swan queues an on-chain withdrawal to that address.

faqs.q: Who holds custody of bitcoin bought on Swan?
faqs.a: Swan opens an individually titled account for you with regulated custodians Bakkt, BitGo, or Equity Trust, and those partners do not lend or rehypothecate customer coins. You can leave funds there temporarily or withdraw to your own wallet whenever you are ready.

fees.intro: Zero-fee onboarding on the first $10,000 in lifetime buys, 1% after that, plus optional custody programs billed separately.

dca: Yes: but with fees after the first $10.000
description:
Swan Bitcoin, launched by Cory Klippsten and based in California, is a platform focused on making it easy for beginners to buy and save Bitcoin.

What makes Swan distinct is its focus on self-custody support and education. It automatically withdraws BTC weekly to your own address and provides guides for self-custody, while also offering Swan Guard with fraud protection and identity verification tools. Swan prioritizes teaching users about Bitcoin's value for financial freedom. Swan also targets long-term savers by offering IRA products making Bitcoin tax-advantaged retirement savings easier.

Swan offers zero-fee purchases on the first $10,000, a low 0.99% fee for recurring buys, and free withdrawals to personal wallets, encouraging self-custody. Its app is praised for its clean design and simple setup. However, some users report slow customer support and issues with account restrictions.

Its vision is to onboard 10 million Bitcoin users by promoting Bitcoin as better money for a decentralized future.
recovery_method: One-time passcode email login with optional authenticator app 2FA.

tl_dr.best_for: Long-term bitcoin buyers who want zero fees on their first $10,000 and concierge paths into self-custody.
tl_dr.consider_if: You value regulated custody partners, Swan Vault backups, or IRA automation alongside recurring buys.
tl_dr.not_ideal_when: You need instant Lightning payments or want to avoid full KYC disclosures.

steps.title: 1. Create & verify
actions: Sign up at swanbitcoin.com or install the Swan app and enter your email to receive a one-time passcode.
Complete identity verification with your legal name, address, and government ID.
Turn on authenticator-based 2FA before funding so withdrawals stay protected.
steps.gotcha: Swan only supports customers over 18 with a U.S. government ID and an eligible bank account.

steps.title: 2. Link your funding
actions: Open the main menu → Bank Accounts and add a U.S. checking account (ACH is required for transfers).
Double-check you entered the ACH routing number rather than the wire routing number.
For large buys, request wire instructions from the Funding section so your bank can send same-day cash.
steps.gotcha: Small fintech banks and savings-only accounts may be rejected by the account verification system.

steps.title: 3. Buy & schedule withdrawal
steps.why: Automate your stacking while keeping a clear exit to self-custody.
actions: Start a one-time or recurring plan; Swan pulls ACH purchases on your chosen cadence.
Watch the “Available to withdraw” timeline so you know when ACH-funded bitcoin unlocks.
Add your wallet in Withdrawals and set auto-withdraw so sats leave custody as soon as they unlock.
steps.gotcha: ACH-funded bitcoin cannot move until its unlock window closes, even if you trigger auto-withdraw.

micro_faqs.q: Can I fund Swan with a savings account?
micro_faqs.a: No. Swan requires a U.S. checking account that supports ACH transfers for recurring buys.

micro_faqs.q: Where do I see my unlock dates?
micro_faqs.a: Open the dashboard banner labeled “Available to withdraw” to view the exact release schedule for each ACH purchase.

micro_faqs.q: Do auto-withdrawals require 2FA?
micro_faqs.a: Yes. Swan asks you to enable two-factor authentication before it will approve a new withdrawal address or auto-withdraw rule.

name: Umbrel

faqs.q: What hardware does Umbrel officially support?
faqs.a: Umbrel Home ships with pre-configured hardware, but you can flash the same umbrelOS image onto Raspberry Pi 5/4 kits or x86 mini-PCs with at least 8 GB RAM and SSD storage.

faqs.q: How are Lightning channel backups handled?
faqs.a: Umbrel can generate static channel backup (SCB) files from the Lightning dashboard and also stores encrypted copies under `/home/umbrel/umbrel/lnd/data/chain/bitcoin/mainnet/channel.backup`, so you can restore after hardware failures.

faqs.q: What about the default password?
faqs.a: Every Umbrel instance ships with `moneyprintergobrrr` as the default dashboard password; change it on first boot and generate unique credentials for Thunderhub or other apps that keep their own login store.

supported_network: Bitcoin full node, Lightning, and 100+ self-hosted apps

WW.text: Built-in Tor routing for remote access
HTTP-only dashboard unless you front it with HTTPS yourself

custody_control: Self-hosted (you run the node and keys locally)
recovery_method: System backup archive + Lightning static channel backup
description:
Umbrel bundles Bitcoin Core, Lightning daemons, and a catalog of home-server apps into a single dashboard you host on your own hardware. Because your node verifies blocks locally, you no longer depend on third-party APIs for mempool data or wallet balances, and the App Store manages containers for tools like Electrs, Mempool, BTCPay, or even photo libraries without touching the command line.

That convenience comes with trade-offs. Umbrel keeps its UI on HTTP inside your LAN, uses a source-available license, and manages updates centrally, so you inherit their defaults unless you harden the stack with Tor-only access, VLAN isolation, and custom reverse proxies. You can export backups, disable telemetry, and lock down SSH, but long-term safety still depends on how you provision hardware, power, and backups.

Use Umbrel when you want a polished, guided path into running your own Bitcoin stack alongside other self-hosted services. If you need reproducible builds, deterministic updates, or air-gapped security policies, treat Umbrel as a starter kit and graduate to a more open stack once you’re comfortable maintaining the moving pieces.

tl_dr.best_for: People who want a guided home server to run Bitcoin, Lightning, and household apps without SSH.
tl_dr.consider_if: You like plug-and-play UX but still want Tor routing, Electrs, and containerized services under your roof.
tl_dr.not_ideal_when: You require fully open-source licensing, HTTPS-by-default, or granular control over every dependency.

steps.title: 1. Flash umbrelOS for Raspberry Pi
steps.sync_time: ~5–6 days on Pi 4, leave device on.
actions: Download the latest umbrelOS `.img.xz` from GitHub Releases
Flash it to a fast microSD using Balena Etcher and plug in your USB 3.0 SSD for blockchain data
Attach Ethernet before first boot so the node can reach peers immediately
steps.gotcha: Slow microSD cards throttle sync speed; favor A2-rated or better.

steps.title: 2. First boot & start syncing
actions: Visit `umbrel.local` or the IP, accept onboarding, and replace the default password
Install Bitcoin Core and Lightning from the App Store and start the sync
Leave the device on; initial sync on Pi can take 4–6 days depending on peers
steps.gotcha: Do not send funds until Bitcoin Core shows 100% synchronization.

steps.title: 3. Install on an x86 mini PC
steps.sync_time: ~12–18 hours on N100, leave device on.
actions: Write the umbrelOS ISO to a USB stick, boot your Intel/AMD mini PC, and follow the guided installer
Select the SSD as the target disk; the installer partitions and provisions services automatically
Keep Ethernet connected for the first sync—expect 12–18 hour initial block download
steps.gotcha: The installer wipes the entire target disk; back up any existing data first.

steps.title: 4. Run inside a Linux VM or Docker host
actions: Provision a Debian/Ubuntu host with Docker and compose, then run the official curl installer with `--install-path` pointing to your storage volume
Expose port 3000 only inside your LAN; route remote access through Tor or a VPN instead of opening it on the internet
Snapshot the VM before major upgrades so you can roll back quickly
steps.gotcha: Umbrel expects direct disk access; thin-provisioned volumes can bottleneck IBD.

micro_faqs.q: Can I reuse an external SSD that already holds blockchain data?
micro_faqs.a: Yes. Copy the existing `bitcoin` directory into `/home/umbrel/umbrel/bitcoin` before first boot to save days of syncing.

micro_faqs.q: Does Umbrel require a static IP?
micro_faqs.a: No, but reserving a DHCP lease keeps Onion links, Electrs endpoints, and wallet connections predictable.

hardware_bom.heading: Hardware BOM & capacity planning
hardware_bom.intro: Umbrel runs on hardware you control. That means you choose the trade-offs between noise, cost, and performance. Pick a build that matches your app usage, but prioritize SSD storage and a wired connection to keep the node healthy.

builds.name: Budget Pi kit
builds.use_case: Learning, personal routing, light app usage
builds.tradeoff: You save money upfront → You risk sync stalls on heavy apps like Mempool.
builds.assumptions: Requires wired Ethernet + NVMe SSD (SD cards will fail).
builds.gotcha: Pi 4/5 shares bandwidth between USB and Network, which bottlenecks the initial sync.
parts: 1 TB NVMe SSD in USB 3.2 enclosure
Active cooling case or fan hat

builds.name: Quiet mini-PC
builds.use_case: Daily Lightning use, Electrs, media apps
builds.tradeoff: You pay slightly more → You get instant dashboard loads and reliable indexing.
builds.storage_guidance: 2 TB NVMe (Allows Electrs index + Media apps).
builds.gotcha: Requires flashing an OS image to internal disk (wipes the drive).
parts: Intel N100 / N305 mini PC with 16 GB RAM

builds.name: Power user workstation
builds.use_case: Routing, BTCPay merchants, AI / media workloads
builds.tradeoff: High power/cost → You run everything without lag.
builds.gotcha: Overkill for just Bitcoin; only build this if you host AI models or 50+ apps.
parts: Ryzen 7 / Intel i7 SFF box with 32 GB RAM

micro_faqs.q: Is a Raspberry Pi 5 worth it over a Pi 4?
micro_faqs.a: Yes. The PCIe bus on the Pi 5 allows much faster NVMe speeds, cutting sync times by ~30% compared to the Pi 4's USB bottleneck.

micro_faqs.q: Do I really need an SSD?
micro_faqs.a: Absolutely. HDDs cannot handle the random I/O required for block verification; your node will stall and never catch up to the tip.

micro_faqs.q: Can I start small and upgrade?
micro_faqs.a: Yes. You can migrate your data directory from a Pi to a Mini-PC later, but start with at least a 1TB drive to avoid painful migrations.

micro_faqs.q: How much bandwidth does a node use?
micro_faqs.a: Expect ~600GB for the initial download, then 20-50GB/month for gossip. Check your ISP data caps.

fees_scenarios.title: Initial sync time
fees_scenarios.service_factor: Apps remain locked until 100% sync to ensure dependency integrity.
fees_scenarios.what_happens: Bitcoin Core verifies every block from genesis on your hardware (CPU + disk-IO bound).
fees_scenarios.how_to_minimize: Leave it on, use wired Ethernet, and prefer SSDs over HDDs.
fees_scenarios.learn_more: Pause heavy App Store installs until Bitcoin Core reaches tip; Lightning depends on a fully synced node.

fees_scenarios.title: Disk growth
fees_scenarios.service_factor: Unified storage means media apps (Immich/Nextcloud) compete directly with chain data.
fees_scenarios.what_happens: Full-history nodes store the entire blockchain plus Lightning databases, logs, and app containers on your local drive.
fees_scenarios.how_to_minimize: Allocate at least a 1 TB SSD for full archival, or enable pruning to fit on smaller drives.
fees_scenarios.learn_more: Keep >15% free space in `/home/umbrel/umbrel/bitcoin/blocks` so compaction never stalls.

fees_scenarios.title: Power consumption
fees_scenarios.service_factor: UmbrelOS disables disk spin-down to maintain instant Lightning routing response.
fees_scenarios.what_happens: Your node stays online 24/7 to verify blocks and route payments, drawing continuous power.
fees_scenarios.how_to_minimize: Use efficient N100 hardware or under-volt your Pi to keep carrying costs low.
fees_scenarios.learn_more: Pair the node with a smart plug or UPS that reports load so you can budget uptime.

fees_scenarios.title: Bandwidth requirements
fees_scenarios.service_factor: Background Docker image updates add substantial usage beyond chain gossip.
fees_scenarios.what_happens: The node peers with the network to relay blocks and gossip, using significant upstream bandwidth.
fees_scenarios.how_to_minimize: Use a wired connection and set upload caps in Bitcoin Core if your ISP limits data.
fees_scenarios.learn_more: ISPs with 1 TB caps may throttle after long IBD sessions; consider fiber or business-class plans.

fees_faq.q: Can I pause the initial block download without corrupting data?
fees_faq.a: Yes. Shut down from Settings → System before powering off; Bitcoin Core resumes where it left off as long as the SSD stays connected.

fees_faq.q: What happens when my SSD fills up?
fees_faq.a: Umbrel warns you at ~85% usage. Add a larger disk and migrate the `/home/umbrel/umbrel` directory before the drive hits 100% or Bitcoin Core will halt.

key_terms.definition: Encrypted snapshot of your Lightning channels you import if the node fails.
The first sync where Bitcoin Core verifies every block since 2009.
Battery pack that keeps the node online long enough for safe shutdowns.

data_flows: The dashboard listens on HTTP inside your LAN; remote access should route over Tor or a VPN tunnel to avoid exposing logins.
Each App Store container may open additional ports—review them before forwarding anything past your firewall.
Umbrel’s optional telemetry is opt-in; leave it disabled if you want the node completely local.
privacy.data_flows_do: Keep the device behind a router, enable Tor remote access, and rotate credentials that ship with defaults.
privacy.data_flows_dont: Expose `umbrel.local:80` directly to the internet or reuse the same password across Thunderhub, Lightning Terminal, and the base OS.
privacy.recovery_title: Hardware failure? How Umbrel recovery works
recovery: System backups live under `Settings → Backup`; store a copy off-device together with your Lightning SCB file.
To restore, flash the latest image, drop your backup archive plus `channel.backup` into `/home/umbrel/umbrel/backups`, and follow the wizard.
If the hardware dies without a recent SCB, force-close channels from peers or use watchtower data where available.
privacy.recovery_do: Test restores on spare hardware or a VM so you understand the flow before an outage.
privacy.recovery_dont: Rely solely on Umbrel’s cloud-encrypted SCB—keep your own copy.
region: Umbrel runs entirely on your hardware, so jurisdictional limits tie to hardware import rules rather than app access.
Tor helps when your ISP uses CGNAT; you can still reach the node remotely without opening ports.

micro_faqs.q: Does Umbrel support HTTPS?
micro_faqs.a: Not out of the box; front it with Caddy, Traefik, or Tailscale funnel if you need TLS and granular access control.

micro_faqs.q: Can ISPs see what I'm hosting?
micro_faqs.a: They see encrypted Bitcoin traffic and Tor circuits, but not the app data itself—still, avoid exposing clearnet ports.

micro_faqs.q: Where are SSH keys stored?
micro_faqs.a: Umbrel disables SSH by default; when enabled, keys live under `/home/umbrel/.ssh` so you can rotate them like any Linux host.

glossary.def: Carrier-grade NAT that prevents inbound port forwards; Tor or VPN tunnels bypass it.
Static Channel Backup—an encrypted snapshot of your Lightning channels you need after catastrophic loss.

integrations.intro: Your node replaces the cloud. Learn how to verify your own transactions, route payments, and monitor the network privately.

cards.title: Connect your wallet
cards.description: Don't trust your wallet provider with your balance. Connect any Electrum-compatible wallet to your node to verify transactions yourself.
steps: Install **Electrs** from the App Store and wait for the index to complete.
Copy the **Local IP** (desktop) or **Tor Address** (mobile) from the Electrs app.
Paste it into your wallet’s 'Server' or 'Network' settings.

cards.description: Manage channels and route payments from your phone. Connect via Tor so you can sign transactions from anywhere without a VPN.

tasks.title: Export LND channel backup
tasks.intro: Channels are live smart contracts. If your node fails without the latest state, you lose funds.
steps: Go to **Settings** → **Lightning**.
Click the three dots icon and select **Backup channels**.
Save the `channel.backup` file to a separate device.

tasks.title: Run a system backup
tasks.intro: System backups capture your app data and configs (excluding the blockchain). That means you can restore your entire dashboard state after a re-flash without re-configuring every app manually.
steps: Go to **Settings** → **Backup**.
Click **Create Backup** and wait for the archive to download.
Store it offline or on encrypted cloud storage.

tasks.title: Safe update checks
tasks.intro: Updates can break apps. Verify safety before you click to avoid downtime.
steps: Check the dashboard for the orange update badge.
Read the [Changelog](https://github.com/getumbrel/umbrel/releases) for breaking changes.
Click **Update** and confirm Bitcoin Core resumes syncing.

tasks.title: Check storage health
tasks.intro: SSDs wear out over time. Catching failures early prevents blockchain corruption.
steps: Go to **Settings** → **Storage** to view usage.
Ensure you have >15% free space for database compaction.
If usage is high, prune Bitcoin Core or migrate to a larger disk.

security_model.overview: Umbrel assumes a trusted LAN with password-protected web UI, optional Tor remote access, and disabled-by-default SSH.
quick_wins: Change the default `moneyprintergobrrr` password immediately and store it in a password manager.
Enable two-factor auth on Tor gateways like Tailscale or Cloudflare Tunnel if you expose the dashboard remotely.
Segment the node onto its own VLAN or dedicated Wi-Fi SSID so IoT devices never reach it directly.
hardening: Enable SSH only when needed and restrict it to key-based logins.
Mount disks with LUKS or hardware encryption if the device lives outside your home.
Audit installed apps; remove anything you no longer run to reduce attack surface.

migration.title: Reuse an existing Bitcoin data directory
migration.choose: Use this when migrating from another node so you don’t redownload the chain.
steps: Shut down the old node cleanly and copy `blocks` + `chainstate` to external storage.
Place the data inside `/home/umbrel/umbrel/bitcoin` and ensure ownership belongs to the `umbrel` user.
Boot Umbrel; it verifies the data and resumes at the tip before enabling Lightning.
migration.tips: Match the pruning mode—full-history data cannot satisfy a pruned configuration.
migration.gotcha: Power-loss during the copy can corrupt LevelDB files; verify with `bitcoin-cli -datadir=... getblockcount` before moving on.

migration.title: Migrate Lightning channels
migration.choose: Use this to recover LND channels after hardware failure or when moving stacks.
steps: Export SCBs (or a full data directory) from the old node before powering it down.
On Umbrel, open Lightning → Restore, upload the SCB, and wait for on-chain settlements.
If both nodes are alive, drain channels to cold storage and cooperatively close to minimize fees.
migration.tips: Never run two LND nodes with the same seed simultaneously—channel states will diverge.
migration.gotcha: SCBs only recover balances, not channel states; expect forced closes that take ~720 blocks.

migration.title: Upgrade to a larger SSD
migration.choose: Use when you’re running low on disk space and need more headroom.
steps: Shut down Umbrel and clone `/home/umbrel/umbrel` to the new drive with `rsync -aHAX`.
Update `/etc/fstab` or the bootloader to point at the new disk UUID.
Boot, confirm services run, then wipe the old drive once backups are safe.
migration.tips: Use powered USB enclosures for NVMe drives to avoid brownouts mid-sync.
migration.gotcha: Forgetting to update mount points leaves Umbrel writing to the old disk—double-check before syncing.

name: Unchained

faqs.q: How does Unchained's 2-of-3 collaborative custody work?
faqs.a: You hold two private keys on separate hardware wallets, and Unchained holds a third backup key. Moving funds requires two signatures, which means you maintain full control (using your two keys) while Unchained can help you recover funds (using their key plus one of yours) if you lose a device.

faqs.q: What happens if Unchained goes out of business?
faqs.a: Since you hold two of the three keys, you can always move your bitcoin without Unchained's permission or participation. You can use their open-source tool, Caravan, or other multisig wallets like Sparrow to recover your funds using your own keys and backup file.

faqs.q: Does Unchained require KYC documents?
faqs.a: Yes. Because Unchained is a regulated US financial institution that offers trading, IRAs, and loans, you must provide identity verification (drivers license, SSN) to open an account, even for the basic vault service.

faqs.q: Can I use my existing hardware wallets with Unchained?
faqs.a: Yes. Unchained supports most major devices including Trezor, Coldcard, and Ledger. You don't need to buy special hardware; you just export the public keys from your existing devices to build the vault.

faqs.q: How does the Unchained Inheritance Protocol work?
faqs.a: You designate a beneficiary and customized plan today. If you pass away, Unchained guides your beneficiary through a secure verification process and uses their backup key to co-sign a transaction, transferring the funds to them without requiring you to share your private keys while you are alive.

recovery_method: Unchained can co-sign if a key is lost
description:
Unchained is a Bitcoin financial services company focused on helping individuals and businesses secure their Bitcoin through collaborative custody. Their main product is a multisig vault that uses a 2-of-3 key setup, where the user holds two keys and Unchained holds the third. This setup allows users to maintain full control over their Bitcoin while enabling Unchained to assist in recovery if needed, without ever having unilateral access to the funds.

What makes Unchained unique is its emphasis on combining technical security with user support. Unlike standard hardware wallet setups that rely on a single point of failure, Unchained's model is resistant to user error and device loss. Even if you lose 75% of your devices or backups, you can still recover your funds with Unchained's help. Their system also facilitates inheritance by allowing next of kin to recover funds with proper documentation, making it especially appealing for those thinking about long-term wealth protection.

Unchained users appreciate the guided onboarding, live support, and optional concierge services that simplify the complex process of setting up multisig. The platform integrates with popular hardware wallets, and allows users to manage their funds through Unchained's dashboard or export and interact with their vault using open-source tools. The ability to spend from your vault without relying on the Unchained website gives users additional peace of mind.

The company's long-term vision is to build a robust financial ecosystem based on Bitcoin-native tools, including multisig-secured lending, inheritance planning, and business services. While the setup requires ID verification and Unchained knows the vault balances, many users view this trade-off as acceptable in exchange for improved recovery options and strong operational security.

Unchained is best suited for those seeking to remove single points of failure in their Bitcoin custody, want professional assistance when needed, and value redundancy and inheritance planning—all while retaining full self-custody.

tl_dr.not_ideal_when: You require absolute privacy (no KYC) or want to hold small amounts where the setup effort and fees outweigh the benefits.

name: Wasabi

faqs.q: Can I still use CoinJoin with Wasabi Wallet in 2025?
faqs.a: The zkSNACKs coordinator shut down June 1, 2024, so the default CoinJoin option is no longer available. Wasabi continues as a privacy-focused wallet with Tor, coin control, and PayJoin. Community-run coordinators may emerge.

faqs.q: Does Wasabi Wallet always run over Tor?
faqs.a: The desktop app launches with Tor routing and client-side block filters so your IP address and balances never hit a third-party server. You can toggle Tor off for troubleshooting, but privacy drops immediately when you do.

faqs.q: Can Wasabi Wallet connect to hardware wallets or my own node?
faqs.a: Wasabi talks to the open-source Hardware Wallet Interface and can point at Bitcoin Core or Electrum, which keeps signing on dedicated devices while your node answers address lookups. Turn those integrations on if you want end-to-end self verification.

faqs.q: What fees should I expect when using Wasabi Wallet?
faqs.a: The software is free, every transaction still pays the standard mining fee, and CoinJoin rounds add roughly a 0.3% coordinator fee for inputs above 0.01 BTC while smaller inputs only pay miners. You can delay mixes or spend unmixed coins when privacy is less critical.

faqs.q: What do I need to recover a Wasabi Wallet?
faqs.a: Wasabi encrypts your wallet with the 12-word seed plus the optional passphrase, so you must restore with both pieces to regain control. Store them separately and test a dry-run recovery before you trust the wallet with real savings.

profile: Balint Harmat, Adam Ficsor & Gergely Hajdu
description:
Wasabi Wallet is a privacy-focused, open-source, non‑custodial Bitcoin desktop wallet launched by zkSNACKs. It routes all traffic through Tor and uses compact blockchain filters, keeping your IP and balance private. Its standout feature is built-in CoinJoin, a process that mixes your Bitcoin with others' to make it harder for anyone to trace your transactions, enhancing privacy without relying on third parties.

The user interface is straightforward but functional, with a dashboard showing your balance, privacy progress, and transaction history, though it may feel technical for complete beginners. Setup involves writing down a 12-word seed phrase and an optional passphrase, which adds security but requires careful storage.

What sets Wasabi apart is its strong focus on privacy through CoinJoin, which is seamlessly integrated and doesn't require manual setup, making it accessible for newcomers. It also allows advanced users to connect to custom coordinators via platforms like Nostr, ensuring privacy even if default services are unavailable.

Wasabi is for people who want to own their Bitcoin without having to trust big companies. It hides your transactions by mixing them with others, runs silently in the background over Tor, and gives you full control—all on your own computer. Its goal is to make privacy easy and powerful, while building toward a future where you don't rely on any single server.

tl_dr.best_for: Privacy-focused bitcoiners who want a self-custodial desktop wallet with Tor routing, coin control, and PayJoin support.
tl_dr.consider_if: You value mandatory labeling, open-source code, hardware wallet integration, and the option to connect your own node.
tl_dr.not_ideal_when: You need a mobile app, built-in CoinJoin (zkSNACKs coordinator shut down June 2024), or Lightning support.
